paper_abstract: For a given simple graph G, the energy of G, denoted by E(G), is defined as the sum of the absolute values of all eigenvalues of its adjacency matrix, which was defined by I. Gutman. The problem on determining the maximal energy tends to be complicated for a given class of graphs. There are many approaches on the maximal energy of trees, unicyclic graphs and bicyclic graphs, respectively. Let P-n(6,6,6) denote the graph with n >= 20 vertices obtained from three copies of C-6 and a path Pn-18 by adding a single edge between each of two copies of C-6 to one endpoint of the path and a single edge from the third C-6 to the other endpoint of the Pn-18. Very recently, Aouchiche et al. [M. Aouchiche, G. Caporossi, P. Hansen, Open problems on graph eigenvalues studied with AutoGraphiX, Europ. J. Comput.Optim. 1(2013), 181-199] put forward the following conjecture: Let G be a tricyclic graphs on is vertices with n = 20 or n >= 22, then epsilon(G) <= epsilon(P-n(6,6,6)) with equality if and only if G congruent to P-n(6,6,6). Let G(n; a, b, k) denote the set of all connected bipartite tricyclic graphs on n vertices with three vertex-disjoint cycles C-a, C-b, and C-k, where n >= 20. In this paper, we try to prove that the conjecture is true for graphs in the class G is an element of G (n; a, b, k), but as a consequence we can only show that this is true for most of the graphs in the class except for
paper_title: On a Conjecture about Tricyclic Graphs with Maximal Energy
